elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Structure of [Cu(bpz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): (A) 1D linear chains [Cu(bpz)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> aggregate through strong H-bonding between coordinated sulfate groups (shown as tetrahedra) and water molecules producing 2D hybrid coordination/H-bonded network. (B) Formal representation, considering only strongest hydrogen bonds (O⋯O 2.65 Å), of overall 3D structure as inclined interpenetration of the above networks.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

Structure of [Cu(bpz)(H2O)3(SO4)]·H2O (1): (A) 1D linear chains [Cu(bpz)]
n
 aggregate through strong H-bonding between coordinated sulfate groups (shown as tetrahedra) and water molecules producing 2D hybrid coordination/H-bonded network. (B) Formal representation, considering only strongest hydrogen bonds (O⋯O 2.65 Å), of overall 3D structure as inclined interpenetration of the above networks.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">1D ladder type topology in [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (M=Cu <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; Zn <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). In-plane oriented ‘rungs’ of the ladder form H-bonds with nitrate anions coordinated to the adjacent ladder (open bonds refer to ‘interladder’ hydrogen bonding).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

1D ladder type topology in [M(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3) (M=Cu 2; Zn 3). In-plane oriented ‘rungs’ of the ladder form H-bonds with nitrate anions coordinated to the adjacent ladder (open bonds refer to ‘interladder’ hydrogen bonding).

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">2D coordination net of (4,4) topology in [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2MeOH (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). Its planarity originates in inversion symmetry of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand and inversion symmetry of metal coordination environment. Analogous bridging M<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>M with maintenance of network planarity is found for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 3

2D coordination net of (4,4) topology in [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2MeOH (6). Its planarity originates in inversion symmetry of bpz ligand and inversion symmetry of metal coordination environment. Analogous bridging MbpzM with maintenance of network planarity is found for 5, 6, 8 and 9.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Stacking of successive planar coordination (4,4)-nets in [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4MeOH (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>). Perchlorate anions (presented as polyhedra) are disposed in the interlayer space and connect the nets together through dense H-bonding involving OH and NH groups of methanol and <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 4

Stacking of successive planar coordination (4,4)-nets in [Cd(bpz)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·4MeOH (8). Perchlorate anions (presented as polyhedra) are disposed in the interlayer space and connect the nets together through dense H-bonding involving OH and NH groups of methanol and bpz.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View of interlayer region of [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·PhOH (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>). Corrugated coordination sheets are linked by hydrogen bonding similarly to <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>. Guest phenol molecules are incorporated in cavities conditioned by spongy packing of coordination topologies and participate in overall hydrogen bond linkage.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 5

View of interlayer region of [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](CF3CO2)2·2H2O·PhOH (7). Corrugated coordination sheets are linked by hydrogen bonding similarly to 8. Guest phenol molecules are incorporated in cavities conditioned by spongy packing of coordination topologies and participate in overall hydrogen bond linkage.

Three types of bpz orientation with respect to the normal of square planar mesh via the H-bonding with coordinated counter anion: (A) without orientation 3; (B) orientation of opposite sides 6; (C) orientation of all sides 4.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">New organic bitopic connector 4,4′-bipyrazolyl (<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>) easily forms complexes with metal ions and produces 1, 2 and 3D coordination polymers of different topology. Ten coordination polymers based upon <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand and octahedral metal centers (Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) have been prepared and characterized by means of X-ray analysis. In all compounds the bipyrazolyl molecules act as bridging neutral groups and connect two metal atoms at the distances of 9.81–10.34 Å. Representative possibilities for the formation of multidimensional metal-organic array include linear chains in [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, ‘ladder chains’ in [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (M=Cu, Zn), flat and corrugated square grid layers in 1:2 complexes with cobalt chloride, zinc and cadmium perchlorates and copper trifluoroacetate, parallel/parallel interpenetrated square grid layers in [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and 3D diamondoid net in [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. With exception of the latter example the supramolecular architecture of metal-organic polymers may be clearly related with 4,4′-bipyridine derivatives, but more hydrophilic nature of pyrazole nuclei facilitates easy incorporation of different H-bond donors/acceptors—H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH, DMF. The 2D coordination arrays may enclathrate also guest molecules of hydrophilic aromatics that appear to be located between successive coordination layers: [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
New organic bitopic connector 4,4′-bipyrazolyl (bpz) easily forms complexes with metal ions and produces 1, 2 and 3D coordination polymers of different topology. Ten coordination polymers based upon bpz ligand and octahedral metal centers (Zn2+, Cd2+, Cu2+, Co2+) have been prepared and characterized by means of X-ray analysis. In all compounds the bipyrazolyl molecules act as bridging neutral groups and connect two metal atoms at the distances of 9.81–10.34 Å. Representative possibilities for the formation of multidimensional metal-organic array include linear chains in [Cu(bpz)(H2O)3(SO4)]·H2O, ‘ladder chains’ in [M(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3) (M=Cu, Zn), flat and corrugated square grid layers in 1:2 complexes with cobalt chloride, zinc and cadmium perchlorates and copper trifluoroacetate, parallel/parallel interpenetrated square grid layers in [Cd(bpz)2(NO3)2] and 3D diamondoid net in [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](ClO3)2·5H2O. With exception of the latter example the supramolecular architecture of metal-organic polymers may be clearly related with 4,4′-bipyridine derivatives, but more hydrophilic nature of pyrazole nuclei facilitates easy incorporation of different H-bond donors/acceptors—H2O, CH3OH, DMF. The 2D coordination arrays may enclathrate also guest molecules of hydrophilic aromatics that appear to be located between successive coordination layers: [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](CF3CO2)2·2H2O·C6H5OH.

elements.content: <ce:simple-para view="all">A new structurally simple and general tecton type has been introduced into network construction practice. 4,4′-Bipyrazolyl easily forms complexes with metal ions and produces coordination nets of different topology: linear chains, ‘ladder chains’, flat and corrugated square grid layers, parallel/parallel interpenetrated square grids and 3D diamondoid nets. The guest phenol molecules may be incorporated in the interlayer space of 2D coordination arrays.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: A new structurally simple and general tecton type has been introduced into network construction practice. 4,4′-Bipyrazolyl easily forms complexes with metal ions and produces coordination nets of different topology: linear chains, ‘ladder chains’, flat and corrugated square grid layers, parallel/parallel interpenetrated square grids and 3D diamondoid nets. The guest phenol molecules may be incorporated in the interlayer space of 2D coordination arrays.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The interest in the construction of supramolecular coordination networks has permanently increased during the last decade . Rational design of metal-organic polymeric arrays implying the concept of molecular building block or tecton  in context of supramolecular synthesis  has resulted in characterization of a range of new coordination topologies with different metrics. Control of the network parameters through careful selection of the metal ions and organic bridging ligands offers new possibilities for developing functional materials with useful properties. Open framework structures promise catalysts with extra productivity that utilize the advantages of crystallinity , selective and/or reversible sorbents, materials possessing new properties due to incorporation in the tight pores with sides acting as scaffolds , acentric inclusion compounds may exhibit useful electrical and optical  features. Other interesting uses of networks provided by their anisotropy or stucturization .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The interest in the construction of supramolecular coordination networks has permanently increased during the last decade . Rational design of metal-organic polymeric arrays implying the concept of molecular building block or tecton  in context of supramolecular synthesis  has resulted in characterization of a range of new coordination topologies with different metrics. Control of the network parameters through careful selection of the metal ions and organic bridging ligands offers new possibilities for developing functional materials with useful properties. Open framework structures promise catalysts with extra productivity that utilize the advantages of crystallinity , selective and/or reversible sorbents, materials possessing new properties due to incorporation in the tight pores with sides acting as scaffolds , acentric inclusion compounds may exhibit useful electrical and optical  features. Other interesting uses of networks provided by their anisotropy or stucturization .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Important and most general representatives of the tectons that are currently employed for the rational design of solid state functionality are bitopic rod-like molecules (cf. pyrazine, 4,4′-bipyridyl, <ce:italic>bipy</ce:italic>; 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne, etc. ), structural simplicity of which in many cases allowed predictable construction of multidimensional structures. It seems especially attractive to control the metrics of the resulting net arrays and their inherent properties by careful tuning the tecton structure, donor properties and mutual spatial alignment of binding sites. In this context novel perspectives for the design of coordination polymers may be offered by molecules that possess structural simplicity of the above ligands and special properties such as ability to form coordination polymers either in neutral and anionic forms and to serve as efficient donor of hydrogen bond for effective control the counter anion position and enclathration of hydrophilic guest species. Recent work revealed conformational features of prototypical compound, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethyl-4,4′-bipyrazolyl, as an angular connector for construction of coordination and H-bonded polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Important and most general representatives of the tectons that are currently employed for the rational design of solid state functionality are bitopic rod-like molecules (cf. pyrazine, 4,4′-bipyridyl, bipy; 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne, etc. ), structural simplicity of which in many cases allowed predictable construction of multidimensional structures. It seems especially attractive to control the metrics of the resulting net arrays and their inherent properties by careful tuning the tecton structure, donor properties and mutual spatial alignment of binding sites. In this context novel perspectives for the design of coordination polymers may be offered by molecules that possess structural simplicity of the above ligands and special properties such as ability to form coordination polymers either in neutral and anionic forms and to serve as efficient donor of hydrogen bond for effective control the counter anion position and enclathration of hydrophilic guest species. Recent work revealed conformational features of prototypical compound, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethyl-4,4′-bipyrazolyl, as an angular connector for construction of coordination and H-bonded polymers .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">An exceptional paradigm combining the above features is neutral unsubstituted 4,4′-bipyrazolyl (<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>) that may be best clearly related with 4,4′-bipyridine family. This planar molecule  may act either as angular or linear connector between two metal centers depending whether on <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>- or <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-disposition of the N and NH functions. The latter ones, as an efficient H-bond donor, establish possibilities for modeling of inclusion materials with the coordination network surface acting as an active ‘scaffolds’ by hydrogen bonding, while NH⋯O bonding with counter anions furnish possibilities for control on the coordination center geometry and thus on the structure aggregation. In the present contribution we report engineering of characteristic representatives of 1, 2 and 3D coordination network topologies exploiting functionality of this novel connector for supramolecular synthesis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: An exceptional paradigm combining the above features is neutral unsubstituted 4,4′-bipyrazolyl (bpz) that may be best clearly related with 4,4′-bipyridine family. This planar molecule  may act either as angular or linear connector between two metal centers depending whether on cis- or trans-disposition of the N and NH functions. The latter ones, as an efficient H-bond donor, establish possibilities for modeling of inclusion materials with the coordination network surface acting as an active ‘scaffolds’ by hydrogen bonding, while NH⋯O bonding with counter anions furnish possibilities for control on the coordination center geometry and thus on the structure aggregation. In the present contribution we report engineering of characteristic representatives of 1, 2 and 3D coordination network topologies exploiting functionality of this novel connector for supramolecular synthesis.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">4,4′-Bipyrazolyl originally was synthesized by Trofimenko in a laborious nine step procedure starting with diethyl succinate via 3,4-diformylfuran and 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide intermediates . Unfortunately, bipyrazolyls are inaccessible through Ullmann coupling of 4-halogenated pyrazoles . A more efficient way to 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide, that is the closest precursor to <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>, is hydrolysis of bis-trimethinium salts [(R<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC(CHNR<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Synthesis
4,4′-Bipyrazolyl originally was synthesized by Trofimenko in a laborious nine step procedure starting with diethyl succinate via 3,4-diformylfuran and 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide intermediates . Unfortunately, bipyrazolyls are inaccessible through Ullmann coupling of 4-halogenated pyrazoles . A more efficient way to 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide, that is the closest precursor to bpz, is hydrolysis of bis-trimethinium salts [(R2NCH)2CC(CHNR2)2]2+.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Solid [(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC(CHNMe<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (22.71 g, 0.05 mol)  was added to a solution of NaOH (10.06 g, 0.25 mol) in 60 ml water and the mixture was heated for 12 min on water bath with external temperature at 80–82<ce:hsp sp="0.5"></ce:hsp>°C. Total dissolution of perchlorate and evolution of dimethylamine was observed within minutes; slightly yellow solution was acidified with HCl (1:1) to pH 3 and excess of hydrazine hydrate (8.0 ml) was added at once with stirring. Resulting yellow–brown mixture was left overnight, the deposit of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> was filtered off and recrystallized from aq. DMF to yield 5.51 g (82%) of colorless crystals. They are stable on air and did not melt up to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.5"></ce:hsp>°C (!) and very poorly soluble in all usual solvents. Solubility in DMF at r.t. is 0.73 g/100 ml. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (Bruker, 400 MHz, DMSO-d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> ppm): 7.78 (4H, CH), 12.74 (2H, NH).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Solid [(Me2NCH)2CC(CHNMe2)2](ClO4)2 (22.71 g, 0.05 mol)  was added to a solution of NaOH (10.06 g, 0.25 mol) in 60 ml water and the mixture was heated for 12 min on water bath with external temperature at 80–82°C. Total dissolution of perchlorate and evolution of dimethylamine was observed within minutes; slightly yellow solution was acidified with HCl (1:1) to pH 3 and excess of hydrazine hydrate (8.0 ml) was added at once with stirring. Resulting yellow–brown mixture was left overnight, the deposit of bpz was filtered off and recrystallized from aq. DMF to yield 5.51 g (82%) of colorless crystals. They are stable on air and did not melt up to 300°C (!) and very poorly soluble in all usual solvents. Solubility in DMF at r.t. is 0.73 g/100 ml. 1H NMR (Bruker, 400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 7.78 (4H, CH), 12.74 (2H, NH).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Zinc and cadmium complexes with <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> are sparingly soluble in alcohols. Crystallization of coordination polymers was conducted under slow diffusion of CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> vapors into solutions of the components in MeOH. Colorless prismatic crystals of the nitrate complexes possess different stoichiometry: [Zn(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), while metal perchlorates form isomorphous compounds [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>: M=Cd, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=4; <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>: M=Zn, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=3.5).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Zinc and cadmium complexes with bpz are sparingly soluble in alcohols. Crystallization of coordination polymers was conducted under slow diffusion of CHCl3 vapors into solutions of the components in MeOH. Colorless prismatic crystals of the nitrate complexes possess different stoichiometry: [Zn(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3) (3) and [Cd(bpz)2(NO3)2] (4), while metal perchlorates form isomorphous compounds [M(bpz)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·nCH3OH (8: M=Cd, n=4; 9: M=Zn, n=3.5).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Cobalt(II) chloride complexes were synthesized using the layering technique. A typical procedure was as follows: in a glass tube the solution of 0.040 g (0.3 mmol) <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> in 6 ml DMF (first layer), 5 ml of 1:1 DMF/methanol mixture and solution of 0.036 g (0.15 mmol) CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 5 ml MeOH were layered each on the top of the other avoiding interfusion. The crystals of the product grew on walls of the tube as the solutes slowly interdiffused for the period of 7–10 days. The product consists of two complexes, crystals of which were separated manually: [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), light-pink blocks and [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), pink prisms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Cobalt(II) chloride complexes were synthesized using the layering technique. A typical procedure was as follows: in a glass tube the solution of 0.040 g (0.3 mmol) bpz in 6 ml DMF (first layer), 5 ml of 1:1 DMF/methanol mixture and solution of 0.036 g (0.15 mmol) CoCl2·6H2O in 5 ml MeOH were layered each on the top of the other avoiding interfusion. The crystals of the product grew on walls of the tube as the solutes slowly interdiffused for the period of 7–10 days. The product consists of two complexes, crystals of which were separated manually: [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2DMF (5), light-pink blocks and [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2CH3OH (6), pink prisms.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">An easy, but specific procedure was employed for crystallization of copper(II) coordination polymers. Thus, solutions of 0.110 g (0.35 mmol) CuSiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 2 ml water and 0.088 g (0.72 mmol) KClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in 3 ml water were combined and precipitate of K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> was filtered off. To the resulting copper(II) chlorate solution 0.094 g (0.70 mmol) of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> was added and the mixture was stored at room temperature for about 50 days that effected total dissolution of the ligand and crystallization of the complex [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>) as large deep cyan–blue blocks. The yield was 0.14 g (70%). In similar conditions, reaction of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand with aq. solutions of copper(II) salts afforded well-crystalline products: [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), light-green and [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), green–blue. This procedure, under presence of water soluble aromatics, also allows the preparation of inclusion compounds, cf. [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), blue prisms.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: An easy, but specific procedure was employed for crystallization of copper(II) coordination polymers. Thus, solutions of 0.110 g (0.35 mmol) CuSiF6·6H2O in 2 ml water and 0.088 g (0.72 mmol) KClO3 in 3 ml water were combined and precipitate of K2SiF6 was filtered off. To the resulting copper(II) chlorate solution 0.094 g (0.70 mmol) of solid bpz was added and the mixture was stored at room temperature for about 50 days that effected total dissolution of the ligand and crystallization of the complex [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](ClO3)2·4H2O (10) as large deep cyan–blue blocks. The yield was 0.14 g (70%). In similar conditions, reaction of solid bpz ligand with aq. solutions of copper(II) salts afforded well-crystalline products: [Cu(bpz)(H2O)3(SO4)]·H2O (1), light-green and [Cu(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3) (2), green–blue. This procedure, under presence of water soluble aromatics, also allows the preparation of inclusion compounds, cf. [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](CF3CO2)2·2H2O·C6H5OH (7), blue prisms.

<ce:section-title>Crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">

<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor> lists the cell parameters and details for data acquisition and structure solution. Crystallographic measurements for compounds <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> were made using Stoe STADI-4 and Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 diffractometers, respectively; semi-empirical absorption correction was based on <ce:italic>ψ</ce:italic> scans. Data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold> were collected using SMART CCD Siemens diffractometer, the data frames were integrated using <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps> and empirical absorption corrections (<ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>)  were employed. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-square techniques in the anisotropic approximation using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-86 and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-93 . The structure <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> was refined using <ce:small-caps>crystals</ce:small-caps>
. For one of two unique trifluoroacetate ions in structure <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> the CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> group is disordered; in structure <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> the bipyrazolyl ligands are disordered over two orientations, atoms of the guest DMF molecules display high anisotropy of thermal motion reflecting possible disorder. It was not possible to resolve it and the hydrogen atoms for these groups were not included. For <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, three solvate MeOH molecules are disordered over mirror plane. No restraints in bond lengths and angles were employed for structure refinement in all cases. In general the positions of hydrogen atoms were idealized. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold> it was possible to refine positions of NH and OH hydrogen atoms, while for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not located.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography


 lists the cell parameters and details for data acquisition and structure solution. Crystallographic measurements for compounds 5, 6 and 2, 4, 10 were made using Stoe STADI-4 and Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 diffractometers, respectively; semi-empirical absorption correction was based on ψ scans. Data for 1, 3, 7–9 were collected using SMART CCD Siemens diffractometer, the data frames were integrated using saint and empirical absorption corrections (sadabs)  were employed. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-square techniques in the anisotropic approximation using shelxs-86 and shelxl-93 . The structure 10 was refined using crystals
. For one of two unique trifluoroacetate ions in structure 7 the CF3 group is disordered; in structure 5 the bipyrazolyl ligands are disordered over two orientations, atoms of the guest DMF molecules display high anisotropy of thermal motion reflecting possible disorder. It was not possible to resolve it and the hydrogen atoms for these groups were not included. For 9, three solvate MeOH molecules are disordered over mirror plane. No restraints in bond lengths and angles were employed for structure refinement in all cases. In general the positions of hydrogen atoms were idealized. For 1, 4, 6–8 it was possible to refine positions of NH and OH hydrogen atoms, while for 2 and 10 the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not located.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Present polymers of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand involving typical octahedral metal centers (Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) are classified by the dimensionality of coordination network. It is necessary to note two important distinctions between typical linear rod-like connector such as <ce:italic>bipy</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>. Firstly, even if <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> is planar and <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-configured, a perpendicular shift between almost co-directed NM bonds takes place (
<ce:float-anchor refid="SCH1"></ce:float-anchor>). An important special case of linear coordination is demonstrated to show how such successive shifts can be additive, or to compensate each other, depending on orientation around coordination center. Thus the topologies based upon <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> actually can adopt certain flexibility; arrays involving co-directed bonds such as 1D chains or 2D square grids nets can undulate providing zig–zag chains or corrugated 2D layers. Secondly, the close disposition of NH group to coordination binding site can affect on coordination via H-bonding with participation of coordinated counter anion. This succeeds in a certain specific orientation of the tectons around the metal center. Besides, inclusion of H-acceptors via bonding with the same group apparently can be anticipated.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>1D coordination polymers</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Linear polymer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Distorted octahedral environment of a central atom in [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) comprises two nitrogen (CuN are 1.966, 1.975 Å, ∠NCuN 177.05°) and two oxygen atoms of water molecules in equatorial plane, and two long axial bonds CuO with third water molecule and almost detached sulfate anion (2.329 and 2.528 Å, respectively). All four oxygen donor atoms are coplanar. Two nitrogen atoms in copper environment as well as two copper atoms around a single <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> bridge are trans-situated that produces 1D {Cu(bpz)}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> topology in the form of linear chain. These chains aggregate with extensive H-bonding involving coordinated and non-coordinated water molecules, sulfate anions and NH-functions of pyrazolyl groups yielding hybrid coordination/H-bonded layers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>). These layers here approximately 9.64×7.50 Å mesh dimensions and interpenetrate with identical orthogonally situated layers. Overall structure is characterized by very dense H-bonding, for example one sulfate constituting the hybrid square grids layer forms seven hydrogen bonds with O⋯O(N) separations in a 2.65–2.89 Å range. It is interesting to note that orientation of coordinated sulfate anions is controlled by OH⋯O bonding (O⋯O=2.647 Å) with coordinated water molecule instead of pyrazole NH functions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
1D coordination polymers
Linear polymer
Distorted octahedral environment of a central atom in [Cu(bpz)(H2O)3(SO4)]·H2O (1) comprises two nitrogen (CuN are 1.966, 1.975 Å, ∠NCuN 177.05°) and two oxygen atoms of water molecules in equatorial plane, and two long axial bonds CuO with third water molecule and almost detached sulfate anion (2.329 and 2.528 Å, respectively). All four oxygen donor atoms are coplanar. Two nitrogen atoms in copper environment as well as two copper atoms around a single bpz bridge are trans-situated that produces 1D {Cu(bpz)}∞ topology in the form of linear chain. These chains aggregate with extensive H-bonding involving coordinated and non-coordinated water molecules, sulfate anions and NH-functions of pyrazolyl groups yielding hybrid coordination/H-bonded layers (
). These layers here approximately 9.64×7.50 Å mesh dimensions and interpenetrate with identical orthogonally situated layers. Overall structure is characterized by very dense H-bonding, for example one sulfate constituting the hybrid square grids layer forms seven hydrogen bonds with O⋯O(N) separations in a 2.65–2.89 Å range. It is interesting to note that orientation of coordinated sulfate anions is controlled by OH⋯O bonding (O⋯O=2.647 Å) with coordinated water molecule instead of pyrazole NH functions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Ladder type polymer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Two compounds, [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), M=Cu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Zn (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), are isostructural with close geometric parameters. Coordination polyhedron is a distorted octahedron with meridionally disposed three nitrogen atoms of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> and oxygen atoms of a nitrate and two water molecules. As can be expected in case of zinc the octahedron is slightly distorted (ZnN and ZnO(water) are in the range of 2.098–2.129 Å with somewhat elongated ZnO(nitrate) bond of 2.295 Å) against of appreciable distortion in copper complex fully analogous to found for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: four equatorial bond lengths within 1.194–2.005 Å and axial elongated Cu–O interactions with water molecule (2.241 Å) and nitrate ion (2.583 Å).</ce:para>

Ladder type polymer
Two compounds, [M(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3), M=Cu (2); Zn (3), are isostructural with close geometric parameters. Coordination polyhedron is a distorted octahedron with meridionally disposed three nitrogen atoms of bpz and oxygen atoms of a nitrate and two water molecules. As can be expected in case of zinc the octahedron is slightly distorted (ZnN and ZnO(water) are in the range of 2.098–2.129 Å with somewhat elongated ZnO(nitrate) bond of 2.295 Å) against of appreciable distortion in copper complex fully analogous to found for 1: four equatorial bond lengths within 1.194–2.005 Å and axial elongated Cu–O interactions with water molecule (2.241 Å) and nitrate ion (2.583 Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Ladder type topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>) originates in self-assembly of T-shaped blocks and possesses holes (approximately 7×5 Å, M⋯M 9.73 Å) that are entirely enough for encapsulation of pair of parallel nitrate groups from adjacent ‘ladders’ (stand-off at 4.3 Å); inside the quadrangular cavity the former are hydrogen bonded (O⋯N 2.89 Å) to NH groups of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>. Thus ladders are packed in stacks those sides paved with coordinated water molecules and remaining part of nitrate anions. H-bonding between last ones constitutes the whole structure. The ladder motif is one of seven known supramolecular architectures for metal complexes with 1.5 equiv. of bitopic bridging ligands .</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In structures <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the coordinated nitrate anions form weak H-bonds (N⋯O 2.99 Å) with pyrazolyl moieties within the environment of the metal center. This facilitates mutual orientation of the interacting counterparts and the <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> tectons are oriented perpendicular to the ladder plane, thus providing broader holes. Notable, that because the <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> molecules composing the sides of the ladder are not flat (angle between pyrazolyl moieties is approximately 31°), the holes are somewhat smaller as ideally can be. On the contrary, ‘rungs’ of the ladder are disposed in the grid plane as probably dictated by demands of most dense interaction with the encapsulated nitrate groups. Shortest carbon–oxygen separations at 3.24 Å may be attributed to very weak hydrogen bonds CH⋯O .</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>2D coordination nets</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Coordination linkage of all characterized complexes possessing 2D layered structure exists as ‘square grids’ (4,4) nets {M(bpz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (Shläfly topology symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
) with somewhat different metrics (
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>). Metal centers have slightly distorted octahedral environment with closer four N atoms of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> and more distant atoms of chloride or oxygen atoms of counter anions or water molecules. Degree of such axial distortion is maximal in case of copper complex, and appreciable in chloride complexes. In two of six structures (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) the pyrazole cycles of the ligand are not coplanar. Last fact shows that similarly to 4,4′-bipyridine the <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> tecton is not absolutely rigid, but affirms the planar geometry as most characteristic.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Most simple examples among such 2D structures are closely related cobalt chloride clathrates [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2MeOH (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). Independent flat (4,4) topologies (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>) constitute the whole lamellar aggregate. Molecules of methanol and DMF are H-bonded to NH groups of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>. The dimensions of the holes in (4,4) net are enough to fit the methanol, but too little for DMF. Therefore, the separations between topologies are accordingly different and orientation of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> planes in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> provides greater dimensions of the hole. It is interesting to note that interaction of cobalt chloride and <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand in metanol–DMF solution provides simultaneously two individual clathrate compounds with both solvent components.</ce:para>

Most simple examples among such 2D structures are closely related cobalt chloride clathrates [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2DMF (5) and [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2MeOH (6). Independent flat (4,4) topologies (
) constitute the whole lamellar aggregate. Molecules of methanol and DMF are H-bonded to NH groups of bpz. The dimensions of the holes in (4,4) net are enough to fit the methanol, but too little for DMF. Therefore, the separations between topologies are accordingly different and orientation of bpz planes in 5 provides greater dimensions of the hole. It is interesting to note that interaction of cobalt chloride and bpz ligand in metanol–DMF solution provides simultaneously two individual clathrate compounds with both solvent components.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">When the counter anions are weakly coordinating groups like perchlorate or trifluoroacetate, the octahedral metal environment is completed with water molecules and the resulting coordination net is cationic. Isostructural [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4MeOH (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>) and [Zn(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3.5MeOH (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>) are constituted from analogous flat coordination layers, those linked together by dense H-bonding that involves counter anions and methanol molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>). Dense networking takes place due to uncoordinated anions possessing significant affinity to H-bond donors, in present case to methanol. The coordination nets also assist networking, having such H-bonding anchors as NH group of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> and coordinated water molecules.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Especial place among considered structures is occupied by [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) which does not involve hydrophilic guest molecules. It was interesting to query whether the compound exists as a genuine porous network, stabilized by NH⋯O bonding of pyrazole functions and nitrate groups, or the dense packing is dominated by self-inclusion of identical networks. As can be seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG6"></ce:float-anchor>, identical 2D layers [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] interpenetrate producing overall 3D bulk supramolecular structure. It is a rare example for inclined parallel/parallel interpenetration of coordination networks that was observed in its entire form, to our knowledge, only for [Cu(fumarate)(piperazine)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] . This type of interpenetration was also reported for {Cu(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} portion of complicated 3D structure [Cu(bpe)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Cu(bpe)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) . This mode of self-inclusion is succeeded by precise fitting the body of one topology in the holes of other that is the geometric criterion for formation of this densest interpenetration type. It is important that even slight decrease of the holes size may prevent interpenetration, as was found for cadmium nitrate complex with tetramethyl substituted <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> tecton .</ce:para>

It was interesting to query whether the compound exists as a genuine porous network, stabilized by NH⋯O bonding of pyrazole functions and nitrate groups, or the dense packing is dominated by self-inclusion of identical networks. As can be seen in 
, identical 2D layers [Cd(bpz)2(NO3)2] interpenetrate producing overall 3D bulk supramolecular structure. It is a rare example for inclined parallel/parallel interpenetration of coordination networks that was observed in its entire form, to our knowledge, only for [Cu(fumarate)(piperazine)(H2O)2] . This type of interpenetration was also reported for {Cu(bpe)2} portion of complicated 3D structure [Cu(bpe)2][Cu(bpe)(H2O)2(SO4)2]·2H2O (bpe=1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) . This mode of self-inclusion is succeeded by precise fitting the body of one topology in the holes of other that is the geometric criterion for formation of this densest interpenetration type. It is important that even slight decrease of the holes size may prevent interpenetration, as was found for cadmium nitrate complex with tetramethyl substituted bpz tecton .

In cobalt chloride complexes the chlorine atoms forms appreciable  contacts with pyrazolyl NH groups (Cl⋯N at 3.13, 3.16 Å). Despite the H-bonding is really efficient only in case of coordinated nitrate, here is an interesting general possibility to control the orientation of the by H-bond formation within the metal coordination environment (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG7"></ce:float-anchor>). In the instant case the hole dimensions in (4,4) net can be enlarged. Directional control over metal center geometry may permit the control over the topology metric, including degree of layer corrugation, or even engineering of novel networks based on distorted usual geometry of metal center.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A new structurally simple and general tecton type has been introduced into network construction practice. Metal-organic linkage of coordination polymers based upon 4,4-bipyrazolyl tecton may be clearly related with prototypes in a realm of 4,4′-bipyridine polymers and either linear chains, ladders, 2D square grids or interpenetrated square grids topologies may be engineered implying different octahedral metal centers. However, <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-configuration of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> binding sites is also possible and in this case the tecton behaves as an angular connector producing 3D diamondoid array. The more hydrophilic nature of pyrazole nuclei as compared with pyridine facilitates easy incorporation of different H-bond donor/acceptor guest molecules inside the cavities of structure. Effective incorporation of hydrophilic guests in some structures demonstrates the perspectivity of pyrazole-based tectons for engineering of inclusion materials . Orienting of the tecton around the metal core provided by H-bonding within close metal environment potentially is a fruitful crystal engineering method for controlling the metrics of coordination topology.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
A new structurally simple and general tecton type has been introduced into network construction practice. Metal-organic linkage of coordination polymers based upon 4,4-bipyrazolyl tecton may be clearly related with prototypes in a realm of 4,4′-bipyridine polymers and either linear chains, ladders, 2D square grids or interpenetrated square grids topologies may be engineered implying different octahedral metal centers. However, cis-configuration of bpz binding sites is also possible and in this case the tecton behaves as an angular connector producing 3D diamondoid array. The more hydrophilic nature of pyrazole nuclei as compared with pyridine facilitates easy incorporation of different H-bond donor/acceptor guest molecules inside the cavities of structure. Effective incorporation of hydrophilic guests in some structures demonstrates the perspectivity of pyrazole-based tectons for engineering of inclusion materials . Orienting of the tecton around the metal core provided by H-bonding within close metal environment potentially is a fruitful crystal engineering method for controlling the metrics of coordination topology.

metadata.title: 4,4′-Bipyrazolyl: new bitopic connector for construction of coordination networks
